{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3489431,"name":"Val","username":"Otter502","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otter502/{size}/245799_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-22T01:21:05.510Z","cooked":"

I am dealing with an interesting / frustrating issue when trying to implement pathplanner with a yagsl swerve drive.

First off here is the code (I am working off the “swerve” branch): GitHub - Spartronics4915/2025-Reefscape at swerve

I made a basic auto in the pathplanner GUI which:

  • ran a print command
  • followed a basic path (reset odometry was on)
  • ran another print command

When run in the simulator the two print commands run within seconds to each other and the swerveDrive isn’t being given any chassis speeds (or at least not long enough for advantage scope to capture)

When I disable the reset odometry pathplanner tries to re-path to the starting position of the path but seems to “hang”, meaning that the second print command isn’t run (it also isn’t canceling the auto command, I checked this by putting the auto in a command sequence and it isn’t running the next command in the sequence)

I have no clue what’s wrong or where the error even is. Any help would be majorly appreciated!

Autobuilder.config code block 
 AutoBuilder.configure(
            this::getPose, 
            swerveDrive::resetOdometry, 
            swerveDrive::getRobotVelocity, 
            (speeds, FF) -> {shimPublisher.accept(speeds); drive(speeds);}, 
            new PPHolonomicDriveController(
                Drive.AutoConstants.kTranslationPID, 
                Drive.AutoConstants.kRotationPID), 
            Drive.AutoConstants.PathplannerConfigs.PROGRAMMER_CHASSIS.config, 
            () -> {
                Optional<Alliance> temp = DriverStation.getAlliance();
                if(temp.isEmpty()) return false;
                if (temp.get() == Alliance.Red) {return true;}
                return false;
            }, this);
the chassis config 
new RobotConfig( // FIXME replace constants with more accurate values
  Mass.ofBaseUnits(10, Kilogram), 
  MomentOfInertia.ofBaseUnits(1.9387211145, KilogramSquareMeters),
  new ModuleConfig(
      Distance.ofBaseUnits(4/2, Inches),
      LinearVelocity.ofBaseUnits(5, MetersPerSecond),
      1.00, //CHECKUP guess
      DCMotor.getNEO(1),
      6.75,
      Current.ofBaseUnits(40, Amps),
      1
  ),
  new Translation2d(Distance.ofBaseUnits(12.25, Inches), Distance.ofBaseUnits(12.3125, Inches)),
  new Translation2d(Distance.ofBaseUnits(12.25, Inches), Distance.ofBaseUnits(-12.3125, Inches)),
  new Translation2d(Distance.ofBaseUnits(-12.25, Inches), Distance.ofBaseUnits(12.3125, Inches)),
  new Translation2d(Distance.ofBaseUnits(-12.25, Inches), Distance.ofBaseUnits(-12.3125, Inches))
))
Image of pathplanner auto

I was just about to post something similar. We are trying to use the AdvantageKit template with modifications for using a Kraken as the drive motor.

When I run with reset odometry enabled it seems to create the trajectory very briefly and then jumps to the final position. When not using reset odometry it sets the set point to the start location, but immediately quits.

I tried downgrading PathPlanner and the results were different, but never resulted in movement.

Not entirely sure where to look here.

Our code is here

What’s interesting is that, with our code, because I reported the desired chassis speeds I’m almost certain it’s not an issue with yagsl but it’s instead an issue with pathplanner?
It’s finals week for our school so we can’t test on the robot itself but if it isn’t working in our simulator I’m fairly certain it won’t work on a real robot.

I figured out the issue for ours!
We accidentally used .ofBaseUnits(…) which was a user error, .ofBaseUnits assums that the inputted value is in meters / seconds / kilograms. And so we had a HUGE drivebase 12 meters on a side. And 2 meter wheels.
We fixed it in our code base but I wanted to put something here in case anyone else is curious
we found out it was a config error by using the RobotConfig.fromGUISettings() and comparing the config values

we are using meters so sadly this doesn’t solve the problem for us, but it must be something PathPlanner config related.

Turns out the gear ratio was set wrong and caused path planner to not work properly!
